title: Lown–Ganong–Levine syndrome
text:
Lown–Ganong–Levine syndrome (LGL) is a <a href="pre-excitation%20syndrome">pre-excitation syndrome</a> of the heart. Those with LGL syndrome have episodes of abnormal heart racing with a short <a href="PR%20interval">PR interval</a> and normal <a href="QRS%20complex">QRS complex</a>es seen on their <a href="Electrocardiography">electrocardiogram</a> when in a normal <a href="sinus%20rhythm">sinus rhythm</a>. LGL syndrome was originally thought to be due to an <a href="Accessory%20pathway">abnormal electrical connection</a> between the <a href="Atrium%20%28anatomy%29">atria</a> and the <a href="Ventricle%20%28heart%29">ventricles</a>, but is now thought to be due to accelerated conduction through the <a href="atrioventricular%20node">atrioventricular node</a> in the majority of cases. The syndrome is named after <a href="Bernard%20Lown">Bernard Lown</a>, <a href="William%20Francis%20Ganong%2C%20Jr.">William Francis Ganong, Jr.</a>, and <a href="Samuel%20A.%20Levine">Samuel A. Levine</a>.
Pathophysiology.
LGL syndrome was originally thought to involve a rapidly conducting <a href="accessory%20pathway">accessory pathway</a> (bundle of James) that connects the atria directly to the <a href="bundle%20of%20His">bundle of His</a>, bypassing the slowly conducting <a href="atrioventricular%20node">atrioventricular node</a>. However, the majority of those with LGL in whom <a href="Electrophysiology%20study">electrophysiological studies</a> have been performed do not have any evidence of an accessory pathway or structural abnormality. Whilst in a minority of cases some form of intranodal or paranodal fibers that bypass all or part of the atrioventricular node can be found with subsequent conduction down the normal <a href="Electrical%20conduction%20system%20of%20the%20heart">His-Purkinje system</a>, in most cases the short PR interval is caused by accelerated conduction through the atrioventricular node. LGL syndrome is therefore felt to represent a clinical syndrome with multiple different underlying causes.
Diagnosis.
LGL syndrome is diagnosed in a person who has experienced episodes of abnormal heart racing (arrhythmias) who has a <a href="PR%20interval">PR interval</a> less than or equal to 0.12 second (120 ms) with normal <a href="QRS%20complex">QRS complex</a> configuration and duration on their resting <a href="Electrocardiography">ECG</a>. A short PR interval found incidentally on an ECG without episodes of tachycardia is simply a benign ECG variant.
LGL can be distinguished from WPW syndrome because the delta waves seen in WPW syndrome are not seen in LGL syndrome. The QRS complex will also be narrow in LGL syndrome, as opposed to WPW, because ventricular conduction is via the His-Purkinje system. Lown–Ganong–Levine syndrome is a clinical diagnosis that came about before the advent of electrophysiology studies. It is important to be aware that not all WPW ECGs have a delta wave; the absence of a delta wave does not conclusively rule out WPW.
Prognosis.
Individuals with LGL syndrome do not carry an increased risk of sudden death. The only morbidity associated with the syndrome is the occurrence of paroxysmal episodes of tachycardia which may be of several types, including <a href="sinus%20tachycardia">sinus tachycardia</a>, <a href="AV%20nodal%20reentrant%20tachycardia">atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia</a>, <a href="atrial%20fibrillation">atrial fibrillation</a>, or <a href="atrial%20flutter">atrial flutter</a>.
